Award.AwardTitle: Simulating Large-Scale Morphogenesis in Planar Tissues
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cutting-edge developments in biotechnology and medicine involve reconstructing large-scale tissues and organs. This work can be limited by lack of knowledge in tissue morphogenesis, the process by which living tissues develop their size-and-shape characteristics. Though live-imaging techniques have enabled the observation of morphogenetic processes, progress in fundamental understanding has been slow. This project aims to improve tools for modeling a wide range of living tissues that are relatively planar and have been extensively studied experimentally. The project will develop methods for numerical simulation of morphogenesis processes and attempt to reproduce the observed large-scale morphogenesis structures in planar tissues. The project provides graduate student training through involvement in the research.

This project concerns numerical simulation of large-scale continuum models for tissue morphogenesis that involve free boundaries, bulk-interface coupling, and highly nonlinear interactions. The work centers on a new mathematical model in which the field variables are nonlinearly coupled via reaction-convection equations and non-standard spatial partial differential equations. The project will develop semi-implicit and fully implicit time-stepping methods to avoid a potential time-step restriction for explicit time-stepping methods. Due to the high nonlinearity of the system, the boundary configuration must be updated together with the velocity field as well as other field variables. For this purpose, a novel interface-tracking method based on reference-map techniques will be investigated. Linear analysis close to trivial solutions will be conducted to assist the design of fast-converging iterative methods for solving the nonlinear system derived from the implicit time-stepping discretization of the original model. Simulations to understand in vitro micro-tissue and in vivo epithelial-tissue morphogenesis from live-imaging data will be carried out.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to construct and reconstruct large-scale tissues and organs is essential to improving public health and longevity. To reach the goal of freely sculpting living materials, we need to better understand how they respond to externally applied stimuli. In the case of mechanical stimulations, we already know that living tissues can behave as elastic, viscoelastic, and viscous materials, depending on the sample size and the timespan of the physical process. In addition, they can grow in size not only in response to chemical stimuli such as nutrients and growth factors but can also regulate growth through mechanical feedback. Thus, the focus of the project is to develop numerical methods to simulate a wide range of living tissues in 1D radial symmetry and full 2D, which have been extensively studied experimentally. Additionally, we want to understand how tissue fluidity, size, and shape are regulated at the continuum level.

Simulating tissue morphogenesis with free boundaries and new nonlinear mechanics. Previous continuum models have considered tissues as linear fluids or nonlinear elastic tissues and have developed corresponding numerical methods. Since we wanted to describe a wide range of living tissues, we have developed a model framework to describe a family of materials that can behave from linear Maxwell viscoelastic fluids to pure hyper-elastic solids, tuned by a single parameter of internal rearranging rate. In between the two extremes, the model describes tissues as nonlinear elastic solids at every instant but can also deform irreversibly over time, which agrees better with experiments. We have developed finite-difference methods to treat the evolving domain with moving boundaries and the partial differential equation system. The major challenge is that we need to treat evolution equations involving advection while the velocity field is coupled with the nonlinear elliptic equation coming from the minimization of elastic energy at any instant. This is done by considering a surrogate problem where the evolution equations are coupled with a linear system of velocity due to the time-differentiation of the original nonlinear elliptic system. We have applied the numerical method to simulate tumor spheroid growth and large-scale in vitro tissue flow, and the numerical simulation agrees well with experimental data.

What is new in nonlinear viscoelastic tissues? By nonlinear simulation of growing tissue spheroids and discs with graded growth rates along the radius, we have found that tissue compressibility and fluidity influence their equilibrium size. By comparing the nonlinear simulations with the linear analytical solutions, we have shown that the tissue size changes as a nonlinear effect due to the advection of the tissue density flow, which only occurs when both tissue compressibility and fluidity are small but nonzero. This means that this new phenomenon cannot be captured by previous models where the tissues are approximated by linear fluids or hyperelastic materials.

Revisiting simulations of nonlinear mechanics in growth-elasticity. Previous models considering morphogenesis due to growth-patterning and tissue elastic responses have qualitatively explained shape formations in living organs, such as in tubular gut interior surface folding and brain gyrification. To study the birth and evolution of non-trivial solutions induced by growth, most previous numerical studies are based on Newton’s iteration on the nonlinear equation system derived from finite element approximation. Thus, the numerical iterations may fail to converge when the stiffness matrix becomes singular. In contrast, we have developed a numerical method by optimizing the discretized energy functional using an energy-stable gradient descent algorithm. This strategy enables the identification of new solutions that have not been reported before and thus discovers new phenomena from the ideology of growth-induced morphogenesis. In comparison with the cross-section of the tubular gut, we find our simulation agrees better with the experimental observations than previous simulations.

Intellectual Merit: We have identified how the nonlinear interaction between tissue fluidity and elasticity can play a role in size control, which can be used to better understand developmental processes and cancer growth. Three new computational methods were developed (viscoelastic incompressible and compressible cases, and pure hyperelastic cases), which can be used to study large-scale tissue morphogenesis more generally. This research has led to eight manuscripts, six published, one in review, and one in submission.

Broader Impacts: This project has resulted in training for eight undergraduate students, one high school student, one postdoc, and two graduate students. Many scientific presentations were given at conferences to describe the new model phenomenon and the new numerical methods, as well as their applications in experiments.

 


Last Modified: 05/27/2024
Modified by: Min Wu
